sen.j: 女性神職装束（じょせいしんしょくしょうぞく）とは、戦後登場した女性神職のための装束である。
sen.e: Josei shinshoku shozoku is costumes for female Shinto priests, having appeared after the Second World War.
Josei shinshoku shozoku are costumes for female Shinto priests, which appeared after the Second World War.
Josei shinshoku shozoku are costumes for female Shinto priests, which appeared after the Second World War.

sen.j: 神職ではない巫女・舞女の装束は含まれない。
sen.e: They don't include costumes for miko or maihime (shrine maidens) because they are not Shinto priests.
They don't include costumes for miko or maihime (shrine maidens) because they are not Shinto priests.
They don't include costumes for miko or maihime (shrine maidens) because they are not Shinto priests.

sen.j: 本項では、昭和62年（1987年）に神社本庁によって制定された女子神職の服制に基づく衣装を紹介する。
sen.e: This section introduces the costumes based on the dress code for female Shinto priests enacted by Jinja Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) in 1987.
This section introduces the costumes based on the dress code for female Shinto priests enacted by Jinja Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) in 1987.
This section introduces the costumes based on the dress code for female Shinto priests enacted by Jinja Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) in 1987.

sen.j: 旧規定の装束については簡単に説明するにとどめる。
sen.e: The costumes based on the old code are only briefly explained.
The costumes based on the old code are only briefly explained.
The costumes based on the old code are only briefly explained.

tit.e: Transition of costumes for female Shinto priests
Transition of costumes for female Shinto priests
Transition of costumes for female Shinto priests

sen.j: 昭和21年（1946年）に制定された旧規定では、正装に袿袴（けいこ/足の甲までの長さの切袴と言う袴と袿のセット）、礼装に白い袿袴か水干、常装に水干が定められていたが、袿袴姿は豪華だが非常に動きにくかったため、昭和62年に新しい規定が発表され現在に至る。
sen.e: Though keiko (a type of female formal outfit: a set of kiribakama (a instep-length Japanese skirt) and uchigi (or uchiki, a Japanese garment worn mostly inside a coat)) for formal attire, white keiko or suikan (a non-starched garment worn ordinarily in ancient Japan for ceremonial attire, and suikan for everyday attire were provided in the old code enacted in 1946, the new code was published in 1987 because it was very difficult to move wearing keiko despite its gorgeousness, which has continued to date.

Though keiko (a type of female formal outfit: a set of kiribakama (a instep-length Japanese skirt) and uchigi (or uchiki, a Japanese garment worn mostly inside a coat)) for formal attire, white keiko or suikan (a non-starched garment worn ordinarily in ancient Japan for ceremonial attire, and suikan for everyday attire were provided in the old code enacted in 1946, the new code was published in 1987 because it was very difficult to move wearing keiko despite its gorgeousness, which has continued to this day.

Although keiko (a type of female formal outfit: a set of kiribakama (a instep-length Japanese skirt) and uchigi (or uchiki, a Japanese garment worn mostly inside a coat)) for formal attire, white keiko or suikan (a non-starched garment worn ordinarily in ancient Japan) for ceremonial attire, and suikan for everyday attire were provided in the old code enacted in 1946, the new code was published in 1987 because it was very difficult to move wearing keiko despite its gorgeousness, which has continued to this day.
sen.cmt: 括弧を追加しました。ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 現行の衣装は、宮中の下級女官の衣装である采女装束と袿袴を折衷にしたもので活動的である。
sen.e: The present costumes are a combination of uneme shozoku (costumes for lower-level court ladies) and keiko, so it is easy to move wearing them.
The present costumes are a combination of uneme shozoku (costumes for lower-level court ladies) and keiko, so it is easy to move wearing them.
The present costumes are a combination of uneme shozoku (costumes for lower-level court ladies) and keiko, so it is easy to move wearing them.

sen.j: （下の項で説明）
sen.e: (described in the paragraph below)
(described in the paragraph below)
(described in the paragraph below)

sen.j: ただし、旧規定の水干は現在でも使われており、男性の狩衣のように裾を外に出して着付ける。
sen.e: However, suikan in the old code is still used and it is worn with its hem hanging out like male's kariginu (an informal garment worn by court nobles).
However, suikan in the old code is still used and it is worn with its hem hanging out like male's kariginu (an informal garment worn by court nobles).
However, suikan in the old code is still used and it is worn with its hem hanging out like male's kariginu (an informal garment worn by court nobles).

sen.j: 紐を結んで襟をとめるため、狩衣の首にリボンをつけたように見える。
sen.e: It looks like kariginu having a ribbon around the neck, with its collar fastened by lacing up.
It looks like kariginu having a ribbon around the neck, with its collar fastened by lacing up.
It looks like kariginu having a ribbon around the neck, with its collar fastened by lacing up.

sen.j: 他に最近は、狩衣の襟を着物の打ち合わせ風に仕立てた「女狩衣」も普及している。
sen.e: Onna kariginu' (female's kariginu) in which the collar of kariginu is tailored in kimono's uchiawase (overlapping) style is also widely used these days.
Onna kariginu' (female's kariginu) in which the collar of kariginu is tailored in kimono's uchiawase (overlapping) style is also widely used these days.
A costume called 'onna kariginu' (female's kariginu) in which the collar of kariginu is tailored in kimono's uchiawase (overlapping) style is also widely used these days.
sen.cmt: 文頭に一部追加しました。

sen.j: 正装（これを純白でそろえると礼装になる）
sen.e: Formal attire (regarded as ceremonial attire when it makes a pure-white ensemble)
Formal attire (regarded as ceremonial attire when it makes a pure-white ensemble)
Formal attire (regarded as ceremonial attire when it makes a pure-white ensemble)

sen.j: 髪上具：釵子（雛人形の髪飾りと同様の物）と心葉（正装のみ）、日陰の糸
sen.e: Kamiage no gu (a set of hair ornaments): saishi (the same sort of hair ornament worn by female dolls displayed at the Girls' Festival), kokoroba (a kind of artificial flower) (only for formal attire), and hikage no ito (a hair ornament hanging plaited threads)

Kamiage no gu (a set of hair ornaments): saishi (the same sort of hair ornament worn by female dolls displayed at the Girls' Festival), kokoroba (a kind of artificial flower) (only for formal attire), and hikage no ito (a hair ornament hanging plaited threads)

Kamiage no gu (a set of hair ornaments): Saishi (the same sort of hair ornament worn by female dolls displayed at the Girls' Festival), kokoroba (a kind of artificial flower) (only for formal attire), and hikage no ito (a hair ornament hanging plaited threads)
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 唐衣：色に規定は無いが、二級以上は二重織物（夏は紗）紋は縫取織りで表す。
sen.e: Karaginu (a waist-length robe worn at the top): no color is provided, however, futaeorimono (a fabric with another pattern woven from other threads on a patterned fabric) (sha (gauze) in summer) is used for nikyu (the fourth level of status of Shinto priests) and above, with mon (a pattern) woven by nuitoriori (a weave with which another pattern is woven on a patterned fabric as if it is embroidered).

Karaginu (a waist-length robe worn at the top): no color is provided, however, futaeorimono (a fabric with another pattern woven from other threads on a patterned fabric) (sha (gauze) in summer) is used for nikyu (the fourth level of status of Shinto priests) and above, with mon (a pattern) woven by nuitoriori (a weave with which another pattern is woven on a patterned fabric as if it is embroidered).

Karaginu (a waist-length robe worn at the top): No color is provided, however, futaeorimono (a fabric with another pattern woven from other threads on a patterned fabric) (sha (gauze) in summer) is used for nikyu (the fourth level of status of Shinto priests) and above, with mon (a pattern) woven by nuitoriori (a weave with which another pattern is woven on a patterned fabric as if it is embroidered).
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 三・四級は有紋の固地綾（夏は文紗）。
sen.e: Patterned katajiaya (a thick and hard twilled fabric with a clear pattern) (monsha (patterned gauze) in summer) for sankyu (the fifth level of status) and yonkyu (the sixth level of status).
Patterned katajiaya (a thick and hard twilled fabric with a clear pattern) (monsha (patterned gauze) in summer) for sankyu (the fifth level of status) and yonkyu (the sixth level of status).
Patterned katajiaya (a thick and hard twilled fabric with a clear pattern) (monsha (patterned gauze) in summer) for sankyu (the fifth level of status) and yonkyu (the sixth level of status).

sen.j: 大きな式典には小忌衣をこの上に重ねることもある。
sen.e: Omigoromo (a ceremonial coat used for Shinto rites) is sometimes worn on it in major ceremonies.
Omigoromo (a ceremonial coat used for Shinto rites) is sometimes worn on it in major ceremonies.
Omigoromo (a ceremonial coat used for Shinto rites) is sometimes worn on it in major ceremonies.

sen.j: 表衣：色に規定は無い。
sen.e: Uwagi (a robe worn inside karaginu): no color is provided.
Uwagi (a robe worn inside karaginu): no color is provided.
Uwagi (a robe worn inside karaginu): No color is provided.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 特級・一級は綾地に縫取（夏は練薄・縫取・顕文紗）二級上・二級は有文綾（夏は練薄・顕文紗）三・四級は有文綾（夏は顕文紗）
sen.e: A twilled fabric with a pattern woven on it for tokkyu (the first level of status) and ikkyu (the second level of status), patterned aya (a twilled fabric) (neriusu (a silk fabric woven from raw silk and glossed silk) or kenmonsha (gauze with a clear pattern) in summer) for nikyu-jo (the third level of status) and nikyu, patterned aya (kenmonsha in summer) for sankyu and yonkyu.

A twilled fabric with a pattern woven on it for tokkyu (the first level of status) and ikkyu (the second level of status), patterned aya (a twilled fabric) (neriusu (a silk fabric woven from raw silk and glossed silk) or kenmonsha (gauze with a clear pattern) in summer) for nikyu-jo (the third level of status) and nikyu, patterned aya (kenmonsha in summer) for sankyu and yonkyu.

A twilled fabric with a pattern woven on it (neriusu (a silk fabric woven from raw silk and glossed silk), nuitori or kenmonsha (gauze with a clear pattern) in summer) for tokkyu (the first level of status) and ikkyu (the second level of status), patterned aya (a twilled fabric) (neriusu or kenmonsha in summer) for nikyu-jo (the third level of status) and nikyu, patterned aya (kenmonsha in summer) for sankyu and yonkyu.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を追加しました。

sen.j: 単：萌黄色の裏地をつけた紅の綾。
sen.e: Hitoe (a single layer of kimono): deep red aya with a light green lining.
Hitoe (a single layer of kimono): deep red aya with a light green lining.
Hitoe (a single layer of kimono): Deep red aya with a light green lining.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 模様は幸菱
sen.e: It is patterned with Saiwaibishi (auspicious diamonds).
It is patterned with Saiwaibishi (auspicious diamonds).
It is patterned with Saiwaibishi (auspicious diamonds).

sen.j: 切袴：短めの袴で特級は白い固織物に藤丸文様。
sen.e: Kiribakama: short hakama; white kataorimono (a fabric woven tightly) patterned with fujimarumonyo (wisteria medallions) for tokkyu.
Kiribakama: short hakama; white kataorimono (a fabric woven tightly) patterned with fujimarumonyo (wisteria medallions) for tokkyu.
Kiribakama: Short hakama; white kataorimono (a fabric woven tightly) patterned with fujimarumonyo (wisteria medallions) for tokkyu.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 一級は紫の固織物に藤丸文様。
sen.e: Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo for ikkyu.
Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo for ikkyu.
Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo for ikkyu.

sen.j: 二級上は紫の固織物に藤丸文様共緯。
sen.e: Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo tomoyoko (woven from the same thickness of the warp and woof) for nikyu-jo.
Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo tomoyoko (woven from the same thickness of the warp and woof) for nikyu-jo.
Purple kataorimono patterned with fujimarumonyo tomoyoko (woven from the same thickness of the warp and woof) for nikyu-jo.

sen.j: 二級は無地で紫の平絹。
sen.e: Purple hiraginu (or heiken, plain silk) for nikyu.
Purple hiraginu (or heiken, plain silk) for nikyu.
Purple hiraginu (or heiken, plain silk) for nikyu.

sen.j: 三・四級は同じく無地の浅葱色の平絹
sen.e: Pale blue hiraginu for sankyu and yonkyu in the same way.
Pale blue hiraginu for sankyu and yonkyu in the same way.
Pale blue hiraginu for sankyu and yonkyu in the same way.

sen.j: 扇：曲尺八寸五分の十六橋の檜扇に、胡粉など、絵具で色絵を描いたもの。
sen.e: Ogi (a folding fan): about twenty-six-centimeter-long hiogi (a wooden fan) built of sixteen bridges painted with pigments such as gofun (whiting used in traditional Japanese style painting).
Ogi (a folding fan): about twenty-six-centimeter-long hiogi (a wooden fan) built of sixteen bridges painted with pigments such as gofun (whiting used in traditional Japanese style painting).
Ogi (a folding fan): About twenty-six-centimeter-long hiogi (a wooden fan) built of sixteen bridges painted with pigments such as gofun (whiting used in traditional Japanese style painting).
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 六色（白色）の飾り紐。
sen.e: Six-colored (white) decorative lace.
Six-colored (white) decorative lace.
Six-colored (white) decorative lace.

sen.j: 帖紙：紅色の鳥の子紙
sen.e: Tatogami (pieces of paper kept inside the bosom): deep red torinokogami (smooth and glossy Japanese paper).
Tatogami (pieces of paper kept inside the bosom): deep red torinokogami (smooth and glossy Japanese paper).
Tatogami (pieces of paper kept inside the bosom): Deep red torinokogami (smooth and glossy Japanese paper).
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 履：浅沓。
sen.e: Kutsu (shoes): asagutsu (shallow shoes worn by court nobles).
Kutsu (shoes): asagutsu (shallow shoes worn by court nobles).
Kutsu (shoes): Asagutsu (shallow shoes worn by court nobles).
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 一級以上は沓敷きに模様を織り出した白い綾。
sen.e: Patterned white aya is used for the insoles for ikkyu and above.
Patterned white aya is used for the insoles for ikkyu and above.
Patterned white aya is used for the insoles for ikkyu and above.

sen.j: 二級上以下は白い平絹。
sen.e: White hiraginu is used for nikyu-jo and below.
White hiraginu is used for nikyu-jo and below.
White hiraginu is used for nikyu-jo and below.

sen.j: 常装
sen.e: Everyday attire
Everyday attire
Everyday attire

sen.j: 額当（ぬかあて）：黒い紗でできた額当て。
sen.e: Nukaate (a forehead protector): nukaate made of black sha.
Nukaate (a forehead protector): nukaate made of black sha.
Nukaate (a forehead protector): Nukaate made of black sha.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 表衣：唐衣は省略する。
sen.e: Uwagi: karaginu is omitted.
Uwagi: karaginu is omitted.
Uwagi: karaginu is omitted.

sen.j: 一級以上は綾・薄い練絹・縫取織・顕文の紗・平絹。
sen.e: Aya, thin neriginu (glossy silk), nuitoriori, kenmon no sha, or hiraginu for ikkyu and above.
Aya, thin neriginu (glossy silk), nuitoriori, kenmon no sha, or hiraginu for ikkyu and above.
Aya, thin neriginu (glossy silk), nuitoriori, kenmon no sha, or hiraginu for ikkyu and above.

sen.j: 二級上と二級は縫取織を除く。
sen.e: Nuitoriori is omitted for nikyu-jo and nikyu.
Nuitoriori is omitted for nikyu-jo and nikyu.
Nuitoriori is omitted for nikyu-jo and nikyu.

sen.j: 三・四級はさらに薄い練絹も除く
sen.e: Thin neriginu is also omitted for sankyu and yonkyu.
Thin neriginu is also omitted for sankyu and yonkyu.
Thin neriginu is also omitted for sankyu and yonkyu.

sen.j: 単：正装と同じだが省略することも。
sen.e: Hitoe: it is the same as formal attire, however, sometimes omitted.
Hitoe: it is the same as formal attire, however, sometimes omitted.
Hitoe: It is the same as formal attire, however, sometimes omitted.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 切袴：正装に準じる。
sen.e: Kiribakama: formal attire is applied.
Kiribakama: formal attire is applied.
Kiribakama: Formal attire is applied.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 扇：十五橋のぼんぼり扇
sen.e: Ogi: bonboriogi (a fan, a end of which is slightly open even when folded) made of fifteen bridges.
Ogi: bonboriogi (a fan, a end of which is slightly open even when folded) made of fifteen bridges.
Ogi: Bonboriogi (a fan, an end of which is slightly open even when folded) made of fifteen bridges
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 履：正装に準じる。
sen.e: Kutsu: formal attire is applied.
Kutsu: formal attire is applied.
Kutsu: Formal attire is applied.
sen.cmt: コロンの後に続く単語を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 巫女は正式な神職ではなく資格も必要ないため、女子神職のように服制は定められていない。
sen.e: Because miko is not regarded as official Shinto priest and required any qualifications, there is no dress code for miko like that for female Shinto priests.
Because miko is not regarded as official Shinto priest and required any qualifications, there is no dress code for miko like that for female Shinto priests.
Because miko is not regarded as official Shinto priest and required any qualifications, there is no dress code for miko like that for female Shinto priests.

sen.j: →装束に関しては巫女を参照。
sen.e: See the section of miko for their costumes.
See the section of miko for their costumes.
See the section of miko for their costumes.
